  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14582].
  {panel}

h3. Problem

The padlock that signifies page restrictions is too ambiguous. I don't know what it's telling me. Is it saying (a) that I can't edit the page?, (b) that other people can't edit the page?, or (c) that other people can't view the page? Or is it saying all of the above? I have to go to a separate page to find that out. 

To get more information, the user has to click the page permissions lock. This page very comprehensive and may intimidate those looking for only basic information.

h3. Fix

Here's a list of situations and how I'd expect this functionality to work:

- I can't view the page, I can't edit the page: I don't see the page.
- Everyone can view the page, only I can't edit the page: Remove the edit button, don't use the lock.
- Others can't view the page, I can't edit the page: Remove the edit button, add the lock with a tooltip saying "Some other users can't view this page".
- Everyone can view the page, others can't edit the page: Add the lock with a toolstip saying "Some other users can't edit this page".
- Everyone can view the page, no-one can edit the page: Remove the edit button, add the lock with a tooltip saying "Some other users can't edit this page".
- Others can't view the page, others can't edit the page: Add the lock with a tooltip saying "Some other users can't view or edit this page".

h3. Reason for severity

I gave this a major severity because...
- It's pervasive (i.e. on all pages with restrictions).
- There is no middle ground that solves the problem - users are either left with not enough or too much.
fields.summary: Improve padlock (page restrictions) tooltips

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14525].
  {panel}

h3. Problem

When removing a comment on a page, Confluence takes the user back to the top of the page. While this isn't a huge problem in one-off cases, when deleting an entire conversation (with multiple nested comments), repeatedly scrolling back down and finding the same conversation will cause user frustration.

h3. Fix

*Option 1*

When someone removes a comment, go to the permalink of a comment closest to the deleted comment. I imagined it working something like this:
- If you delete a child of a comment, go to the parent comment. 
- If you delete a parent comment, go to the permalink of the child comment. 
- If you delete a singular comment, go to the permalink of the comment underneath.

*Option 2*

When the user clicks "Remove", after confirmation, the comment automatically disappears. The loading and processing of this operation is done in the background.

h3. Reason for priority

While this will cause user frustration it's a limited use case.
fields.summary: Page should stay in the same location after a comment has been deleted.

  {panel}

A user has added watches to pages in different wiki spaces he has access to. These watches were immediately sending email whenever someone modified a page Our user didn't like that, so instead selected the Email Preferences option to "Subscribe to daily updates". 

The user expected the "Subscribe to Daily Updates" to send him a daily email showing ONLY updates to the pages he was watching.

What the user actually got was a daily email showing changes to any pages that the user was able to view throughout the entire system. It was not limited to just pages he was watching.

The new feature request is for the ability to enable daily email notifications, but ONLY for watched pages. NOT for all pages the user can view.
fields.summary: Ability to have daily summary of ONLY watches, not all pages.

Having the page name as the default page title on each page is poor design, since the formatting of titles and page names have two different (and sometimes opposing) goals. I would like either of the following:
1) a macro to specify the page title to be used in place of the page name, or

Display a calendar on a page based on a .ics file attached to the page or space. Macro should include some settings for things like:
type=mini | cal | list   - where "mini" is a small month view with asterisk by dates with events, "cal" is a typical calendar display with events showing, "list" is a text listing.
display=day | work | week | month   - identifying whether to display a single day, work week, full week, or month of events (only work with "cal" and "list" types)
date = <date> - identifying the date to display. For month view it displays the full month containing that date, week view displays the week containing that date.

With the WebDAV plugin, updating of the .ics file could be done via any calendar client, so there is no need for event editing, just display.
fields.summary: Display calendar in page from .ics file attached to page or space. Edit via WebDAV.

* JohnsonEventContainer
* CotnentTypesDisplayMapper
* IndexTaskFactory
* TokenAuthenticationManager
* UserMacroLibrary

What are the plans for Confluence to support the OASIS Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS) TC?

"The OASIS CMIS TC works to standardize a Web services interface specification that will enable greater interoperability of Enterprise Content Management (ECM) systems. CMIS uses Web services and Web 2.0 interfaces to enable rich information to be shared across Internet protocols in vendor-neutral formats, among document systems, publishers and repositories, within one enterprise and between companies."

Here is information about it http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/tc_home.php?wg_abbrev=cmis

I hope Atlassian will participate and support the interoperability services.  This is important so we can use the great features and functionality of Confluence, but have the content reside in our enterprise repositories.
fields.summary: OASIS Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS) TC Support

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14413].
  {panel}

Currently there very few options to configure how attachments are handled. You can only:
- allow or disallow attachments to be added
- allow or disallow attachments to be viewed

What's missing is an option to:
- limit the amount of revisions stored (e.g. only the last 100 versions of an attachment are stored)
- disable versions for attachments at all (only the last revision of a document is stored and displayed)

Background:
It's possible to add/update attachments via Webdav and automated scripts (e.g. cronjobs). This may result in a lot of revisions for the same files (couple of hundreds or even thousands depending on the update frequency). As there is currently no way to purge older versions automatically this will result in a serious performance issue for the Confluence server. We had ~12 attachments on a page that got updated automatically every 30 min. After reaching around 1.500 revisions (roughly 3 months of updates) the page holding those attachments was practically unreachable. The only way to revive the page was by manually deleting all attachments (and therefore all revisions) and re-creating the last revision. This took about 1h for those files and quite some Java exceptions due to timeouts.

If one forgets to purge the files once in a while it might be possible that the page holding those attachments is getting completely unreachable. This would require manual work in the database and the attachment folder to clean up the mess.

If you have the option to add attachments enabled for external users or even anonymous users you have opened the doors for a serious dos attack as it is pretty easy to just spam the page with attachments until it's more or less down. If you have enable Webdav for those users then trouble is to be expected.
fields.summary: better attachment handling, more options

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14211].
  {panel}

Background
----------------

Currently, the Quick Nav tool only indexes (and consequently find matches on) the titles of topics.

However, when people contribute content to a wiki space, they may only wish to segregate discrete chunks of information into sections containing anchored headings within an existing topic. The reasons for doing this are that such chunks of information may be (inter-)related and form part of a more general concept, or they are not deemed important enough for their own topics. For example, see [Searching Confluence|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Searching+Confluence], in which each type of search is presented in its own discrete section (with heading), within the general concept of 'Searching Confluence'.

Hence, it would be great if such headings could be incorporated into the Quick Nav functionality of Confluence.

How should this be done?
------------------------------------

Rather than making Confluence index every heading, I would suggest that only headings which have associated anchors are indexed for the Quick Nav feature. Reasons:
* Confluence needs something tangible (i.e. an anchor) it can use to jump to a specific section of information on a page
* If the author has not included an anchor with a heading, one could assume that they don't deem the associated information is worth searching (at that point). An anchor could always be added at a later time if the associated information is subsequently deemed useful.
* It would probably make it easier to develop - essentially, the Quick Nav indexer would parse a page, look for an \{anchor}, then look for a "hX." (where 'X' is a number) immediately after the anchor and then incorporate the text that follows this "hX." into the Quick Nav index.

How should the Quick Nav tool present these anchored headings?
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

See the attached image for an idea - it relates directly to the example I mentioned above. For example, on the Confluence 2.10 Doc space on CAC, search for "Quick Nav" and it should show something along the lines of what's presented in this image. (Refer to the actual page also!)
fields.summary: Incorporate the ability to identify 'anchored headings' within a topic into Quick Nav.

Confluence's documentation does not make it clear that Wiki Markup is detected by the product's search functions. A customer raised a query about this, so I thought it would be useful to include this information in the product documentation.

AFAIK, Confluence's search functions can search potentially any form of Wiki Markup, with probably a few exceptions like, for example, words beginning with an asterisk ( * ). Pages containing the sought Wiki Markup are presented in the results list. However, the Wiki Markup's textual context is not clearly indicated in this list, because most of this Markup is removed from the search result text.

Kind regards,
Giles Gaskell.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-14144].
  {panel}

I urge you to develop a standalone GUI executable (i.e. Swing) that can configure our servers, so we can handle all Confluence configuration without having to open a single .xml, .properties, or .out file. Things like connection strings, LDAP, license hash, logs, etc.

75% of the problems we've had with Confluence have involved some sort of config file issue, and it's been a complete nightmare to figure out which file does what. To make matters worse, even though we have a lot of Linux servers, people at my company have very little Java and Tomcat expertise (don't ask).

Ideally, between a nice install wizard and this standalone configuration GUI, I would never need to know a thing about Tomcat, Java, XML, etc. and would never need to fire up PuTTY or struggle with vi.

Having a separate GUI-based configuration program would also solve the "bootstrap" issue, where Confluence needs to be working in order to make certain changes to Confluence.

Atlassian could avoid a lot of support costs if you had a tool like this. A lot of the issues we've needed to contact Atlassian support for could have been avoided had we had an easy-to-use Microsoft-like config GUI. (Microsoft SQL Server is a particularly good example.)

If I get some time, maybe I can mock up a UI.

Thanks for listening,
Bill

  {panel}

There is a new option in the Confluence Admin Console, "Trusted Applications". This option allows you to define an application as a trusted application i.e. Confluence trusts the app defined here. So Confluence is the "trusting" app and the defined application is the "trusted" app.

Currently, you can define Crucible as a trusted app, so that the Crucible-Confluence review feature works.

At the moment, the only mention of trusted apps in the documentation is this page:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Setting+Up+Trusted+Communication+between+JIRA+and+Confluence
The above page concerns the trusted comms between JIRA and Confluence, where JIRA is the trusting app and Confluence is the trusted app. This is the other side of the equation, i.e. different from the new "Trusted Applications" option in Confluence. For the new  "Trusted Applications" option, we need to describe Confluence as the trusting app.

For an example of the type of doc we need, take a look at the JIRA doc here:
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/trusted_applications.html
In this doc, JIRA is the trusting application.
fields.summary: Document the "Trusted Applications" option in the Admin Console
